Graphical abstract Electrocatalytic bromine evolution reaction (BER) is significant for bromine production, energy storage, and wastewater treatment applications. Previously reported electrocatalysts for BER either include unstable graphite anodes or precious metal-containing materials. To overcome their disadvantages, this work has proposed, for the first time, the use of nitrogen-doped carbon nanostructures (CNx) as anode catalysts for BER in acidic medium. In terms of BER activity, CNx outperforms both Vulcan Carbon and commercial 10 % Pt/C at bromide concentration as low as 0.025 M. CNx also exhibits high BER selectivity and remarkable stability at highly oxidizing potentials. Tafel slope was measured to be ∼ 120 mV/dec supporting a first electron transfer limiting step for BER on CNx. The high activity and stability of CNx is attributed to several nitrogen-doped carbon sites in its graphitic matrix, which have been examined using DFT. The inclusion of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) intermediates is critical to identify BER active sites accurately, as the most active sites (zigzag pyridinic, zigzag oxide, and pyrrolic oxide) proceed via a OH*-mediated Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. For these sites, DFT predicts that the potential determining step is the first electron transfer to form Br* in agreement with the experimental Tafel slope. Comparison to post-reaction XPS shows good agreement between DFT predicted Br* structures. This work thus provides a direction for the rational design of CNx electrocatalysts for BER. Keywords Bromine evolution Nitrogen-doped carbon Density functional theory BER mechanism Active sites 1 Introduction Bromine evolution reaction is important for several essential processes including the production of bromine and removal of bromide ions from wastewater streams. Bromine production is relevant because it is a necessary element in the manufacturing of flame retardants, pharmaceutical intermediates, oil and gas drilling fluids and for mercury removal from flue gas streams in coal fired power plants [1]. While bromine is undoubtedly an essential entity in several products and processes, the presence of even a small quantity of brominated compounds in potable water as a result of anthropogenic activities such as extraction and utilization of fossil fuels is a serious health hazard due to the formation of carcinogenic brominated trihalomethane compounds [2,3]. Therefore, the removal of bromide ions from wastewater streams, even in low concentrations, is crucial from a health and safety perspective. The bromine evolution reaction is also important in the context of reversible H2 – Br2 fuel cell and redox flow battery [4]. The conventional method of bromine production using the “steaming out process” consists of two basic stages: (i) oxidation of bromide ions to bromine gas using chlorine gas, (ii) purification of crude bromine to produce pure bromine [5]. However, the main drawback of this process is that it requires handling of chlorine gas which is extremely hazardous, thus making the process less safe to use [5]. Moreover, this process becomes commercially viable only when the concentration of bromide ions is more than 2.5 g/l, which is a major hurdle for its application to remove low concentration bromide ions from wastewater streams [6]. Alternatively, bromine can be obtained by electrolysis of HBr, NaBr, bromide-ion rich brines or from effluent wastewater containing bromide ions [5,7]. For the electrochemical process, the anodic reaction can be represented as follows: 2Br- →Br2 + 2e- [Bromine evolution reaction (BER), E0 = +1.07 V]. Electrochemical processes have been previously reported in literature for the oxidation of bromide ions to bromine gas. The Wunsche and Kossuth processes developed in the 1950s and 1960s, respectively, used bipolar graphite electrodes for BER [5]. Similar graphite electrodes have also been popularly used both in aqueous and gas phase systems in other processes that use electrolytic systems for BER [8–11]. However, the instability of graphite electrodes at high oxidizing potentials and their high selectivity towards the competing oxygen evolution reaction (OER, E0 = +1.23 V) resulted in the development of precious metal catalysts for BER, including triple metal oxide coated titanium [5], iridium oxide electrodes/thin films [12,13] and porous platinum/platinum-containing electrodes [14–17]. Previous computational studies have been performed to understand the electronic and structural effects of the specific adsorption of halide ions onto precious metal and transition metal electrode surfaces using density functional theory (DFT) [18–26]. These studies will provide a framework for approaching the modeling of the crucial electrochemical adsorption step of Br- involved in BER. To overcome the disadvantages of the unstable graphite anodes and the expensive precious metal-based catalysts, we have proposed, for the first time, the use of nitrogen-doped carbon nanostructures (CNx) as catalysts for BER [27,28]. These materials, which have been demonstrated to have significant oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) activity in acidic medium by our group [28–39], have been extensively studied by many research groups since then as electrocatalysts [40–45]. Their high ORR activity has been attributed to the presence of different nitrogen sites such as graphitic/quaternary, pyridinic and pyrrolic [35,37,39,46–51]. We have previously also shown these materials to be stable and resistant to carbon corrosion under highly oxidizing potentials in acidic media [35,52,53] as well as in the presence of halide anions [53,54]. In this work, we have demonstrated the high activity of CNx catalyst for BER and its stability and low OER selectivity under BER conditions. Using a combination of experimental methods and DFT calculations, we have explored various CNx active sites for BER, and proposed a possible mechanism through which BER proceeds on the CNx catalyst assisted by OH* species from OER. We have also compared the BER activity of CNx to its counterparts – Vulcan carbon (a form of graphitic carbon) and commercial Pt/C – at Br- concentrations lower than 2.5 g/l. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time a detailed and combined experimental and computational analysis has been presented for the use of nitrogen-doped carbon catalysts for electrochemical BER. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst synthesis CNx catalyst was synthesized by using the method of chemical vapor deposition reported in our previous works [29,31,32]. 2 wt% Fe/MgO substrate was prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of Fe(II) acetate (Sigma Aldrich) on MgO nanopowder (Sigma Aldrich). The impregnated mixture was dried overnight in an oven at 110 °C. 900 mg of the dried impregnation mixture was used as a substrate and spread uniformly across a quartz boat. The boat was placed inside a horizontal furnace and saturated with inert N2 gas at room temperature. The temperature of the furnace was ramped to 900 °C @ 10 °C/min under the inert atmosphere, after which the flow was switched to a stream of nitrogen saturated with acetonitrile (CH3CN) vapors for 2 h. The furnace was then allowed to cool slowly to room temperature. To remove the MgO substrate and exposed Fe particles, the substrate obtained after carbon growth was acid washed in 1 M HCl at 60 °C for 1 h, followed by vacuum filtration and thorough washing with DI water [29,31,32]. The acid-washed catalyst was dried overnight in an oven at 70 °C to obtain the final CNx catalyst. For comparison of activity, 10 % Pt/C (ETEK) and Vulcan Carbon (VC, BASF) were used as received. 2.2 Electrochemical testing Electrochemical half-cell measurements were performed using a rotating disk electrode (RDE) system from Pine Research Instrumentation, Inc. connected to a potentiostat (Bio-Logic). The RDE system was set up with a glassy carbon disk working electrode (Pine Research Instrumentation, Inc.), graphite counter electrode (Pine Research Instrumentation, Inc.) and reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE, Hydroflex) as the reference electrode. All measurements were performed in 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte and the potentials referred to in this work have been referenced with respect to RHE. Catalyst ink for non-precious metal catalyst samples (CNx and VC) was prepared by dispersing 5 mg of catalyst sample in 48 μl of Nafion® and 175 μl of ethanol (200 proof) using ultrasonication. 9 μl of catalyst ink was applied onto the RDE electrode tip by drop-casting method, corresponding to a loading of 800 μg/cm2 geometric. For 10 % Pt/C, 5 mg of catalyst sample was dispersed in 50 μl of Nafion® and 1000 μl of ethanol. 9 μl of catalyst ink was drop-casted onto the electrode tip resulting in a loading of 200 μg/cm2 geometric. To determine BER activity, linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs) were collected from 0 to 1.6 V in bromide-free as well as bromide-containing, argon-saturated electrolyte. Background correction was performed using the procedure described in our previous work [35]. Potential-hold experiments were also performed by measuring the current on the catalyst-coated electrode while holding the electrode potential at a constant value for 10 min. The voltage ramp rate from 0 V to the desired electrode potential was 10 mV/s. NaBr (Sigma Aldrich) was used as the source of bromide anions with the Br- concentration varying between 0 and 0.25 M. Rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) experiments were performed to detect the formation of evolved bromine on the ring while bromine and oxygen evolution reactions took place on the disk simultaneously. On the disk side, a voltammogram was collected from 0 to 1.6 V at a scan rate of 10 mV/s with 10-minute potential holds each at 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 V in an argon saturated electrolyte containing dissolved NaBr at an electrode rotation speed of 1600 rpm, while the ring potential was held at 0.7 V. The ring potential corresponds to the potential at which the bromine reduction reaction is diffusion limited on a platinum ring, as mentioned by Vos et al. previously [16]. Prior to obtaining the ring current, 10 sequential cyclic voltammograms (CVs) were collected by cycling the potential between 0 and 1.2 V. The selectivity (ε) of the catalyst towards bromine evolution was calculated as follows: ε = I BER / 2 I BER / 2 + I OER / 4 where I BER refers to the contribution of bromine evolution reaction to the total disk current, obtained from the bromine reduction current at the ring, corrected for the collection efficiency N, as specified by the manufacturer (37 %). I OER refers to the current associated with oxygen evolution reaction obtained by subtracting the bromine evolution current contribution from the total disk current at the given potential. Accelerated durability testing was performed on CNx-coated electrode by cycling the catalyst between 1.1 and 1.4 V at 50 mV/s in 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte containing 25 mM NaBr. BER LSVs were collected before cycling and after 300, 500, 700 and 1000 cycles. Current densities at 1.2 and 1.3 V were used as a measure of the BER activity of the catalyst before and after cycling. 2.3 Characterization: Post-reaction X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) Post-BER X-ray photoelectron spectra were collected on catalyst-coated electrode tips using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD Spectrometer with Al Kα monochromatic X-ray radiation (1486.6 eV). Glassy carbon electrodes with removable disk inserts (Pine Research Instrumentation, Inc.) were coated with CNx catalyst ink prepared by sonicating 5 mg CNx sample in 24 µl Nafion® and 199 µl ethanol (200 proof). The electrodes were subject to different electrochemical reaction conditions: (i) potential hold at 1.2 V in Ar saturated bromide - free 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte, (ii) potential hold at 1.2 V in Ar saturated 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte with 50 mM NaBr. After the respective potential holds for 10 mins, the electrodes were removed from the electrochemical cell and the glassy carbon disk inserts separated from the RDE tips were used as XPS samples. High resolution X-ray photoelectron spectra were collected under vacuum at room temperature using a pass energy of 20 eV. The spectra were calibrated using the standard C-1s binding energy of 284.5 eV and fitted using the CasaXPS program. 3 Computational Details 3.1 DFT calculation Details All DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna abinitiosimulationpackage (VASP) [55–58] withtheprojector augmented wave (PAW) [59,60] pseudopotentialsprovided in the VASP database. Exchange and correlation effects were described withthePerdew-Burke-Ernzerhof(PBE) exchange–correlation form of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional [61]. All calculations were done withspin-polarizationand witha plane wave cutoff of 400 eV.The total energy calculations were accelerated usinga Fermi-level smearing width of 0.1 eVand dispersion interactions were incorporated through the D3 implementation of Grimme and co-workers [62]. All atomswere allowed torelax until the forces were less than 0.03 eV/Å. Fig. 1 illustrates the ten CNx site models examined in this study. These structures represent the candidate sites that have been proposed in the literature and that we have used in earlier studies of CNx catalysts [46,63]. For basal plane models (Fig. 1d − e), a periodic graphene slab of 9.84 Å × 8.52 Å was used. Zigzag edge models (Fig. 1h − j) are represented by graphene clusters of 9.84 Å × 18.36 Å with 9.07 Å between neighboring ribbons, while armchair edge models (Fig. 1a–c) are represented by graphene clusters of 22.14 Å × 8.52 Å with 11.64 Å between neighboring ribbons. Pyrrolic edge models (Fig. 1f − g) are represented by graphene clusters of 23.52 Å × 8.52 Å with 15.38 Å between neighboring ribbons. All models have a vacuum spacing of 20 Å in the direction normal to the 2D CNx structure. Basal plane models, pyrrolic edge, armchairedge, zigzag edge, andoxidesitesare sampled respectively with a2 × 2 × 1, 2 × 2 × 1, 1 × 2 × 1, 2 × 1 × 1, and 2 × 1 × 1 k-point mesh. We incorporated solvation effects using VASPsol [64,65]. The parameters were set as follows: background dielectric constant εb = 78.4, width of dielectric cavity σ = 0.6, the cutoff charge density ρcut = 0.0025 Å−3 and surface tension parameter τ = 0.525 meV/Å2. The cavity width and cutoff charge density define the transition region from solute to solvent where the dielectric constant smoothly changes from 1 to the bulk dielectric constant. These values are all VASPsol default parameters and are determined by fitting to experimental solvation energies for molecules in water. VASPsol using the default parameters have been used to model a range of electrochemical systems [66–71]. The implicit solvation approach neglects direct water molecule-surface species interactions; however, inclusion of a few water molecules at the interface does not necessarily result in a more accurate representation, and the results can be sensitive to the choice and sampling of water structure around the surface species [66,72–76]. Since for the BER mechanism the only key intermediate is Br*, we would expect a cancellation of errors for any stabilization due to hydrogen bonding across different CNx sites. Therefore, the implicit solvation approach is a good compromise that captures some of the important solvation contributions with low computational cost and reproducibility. 3.2 BER reaction mechanisms and evaluation of potential dependent free energy of reaction We use DFT to examine two main halogen evolution reaction mechanisms: the Volmer-Tafel (V-T) and Volmer-Heyrovsky (V-H) mechanisms [77,78]. The bromine evolution reaction (BER) following the Volmer-Tafel mechanism is described in the following reaction steps: Br - ( a q ) + ∗ A → Br A ∗ + e - Br A ∗ + Br - a q + ∗ B → Br A ∗ + Br B ∗ + e - Br A ∗ + Br B ∗ → Br 2 g + ∗ A + ∗ B where *A represents the first adsorption site, *B represents a second adjacent adsorption site. The last step in the above mechanism is non-electrochemical and will not depend on applied potential. BER occurring through the V-H reaction mechanism is described in the following reaction steps: Br - ( a q ) + ∗ → Br ∗ + e - Br ∗ + Br - a q → Br 2 ( g ) + ∗ + e - As will be discussed in more detail in the results section, the V-H mechanism can also proceed through the second adsorbed Br* species. We refer to this as the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism with the following reaction steps: Br - ( a q ) + ∗ A → Br A ∗ + e - Br A ∗ + Br - a q + ∗ B → Br A ∗ + Br B ∗ + e - Br A ∗ + Br B ∗ + Br - a q → Br 2 g + Br A ∗ + ∗ B + e - The net effect is that for the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism, the BER active site is adjacent to a strongly bound Br* species. We emphasize in this scenario that the strongly bound BrA* species does not turnover (i.e. step 1 is just an initiation step), and that only the last two steps are repeated to produce Br2(g) under reaction conditions. The potential-dependent free energies of each reaction step (ΔGrxn) are calculated through the application of the linear free energy method, referred to as the chemical hydrogen electrode (CHE) when applied to proton-electron transfer steps [79–87]. This method can be extended to any anion-electron transfer steps using the appropriate equilibrium redox potential and has been applied to examine chlorine evolution [18,24,25,88,89]. Underlying the CHE approach is the expectation that the proton-transfer steps have small barriers and that at the potential when the ΔGrxn is zero the elementary step kinetics proceed at measurable rates [90–92]. This approximation should be also valid for the anion adsorption steps for the BER reaction since it does not involve bond-breaking steps. In both the V-T and V-H mechanisms there is an initial adsorption of Br- anions on the surface via electron transfer to the electrode as shown below in Eq. (1) for BER [18,77,78]: (1) Br - ( a q ) + ∗ → Br ∗ + e - where Br - ( a q ) represents the bromide anion in the solvent, * represents the bare CNx catalyst surface, and Br ∗ represents the adsorbed bromine atom on the CNx surface. The bromine evolution reaction is at equilibrium at 1.07 V-RHE at pH = 0. Therefore, the free energy of the Br anion-electron pair can be written as a function of the RHE potential in Eq. (2): (2) G Br - a q - e - = 1 2 G Br 2 g + e U RHE - 1.07 V + k B T ( l n a Br - ) Combining Eqs. (1) and (2) and setting the activity of the Br - anions to be 1, the free energy of the Br anion adsorption reaction step is given by Eq. (3): (3) Δ G rxn U = G Br ∗ - G ∗ - 1 2 G Br 2 g - e ( U RHE - 1.07 V ) The free energy of adsorbed species utilizes DFT calculations and includes the vibrational contributions of the bound species (zero-point vibrational energies, internal energy, and entropy vibrational contributions). 3.3 DFT XPS core-level binding energies There are several methods within DFT to evaluate the shifts in core binding energy (B.E.) [93–95]. While the final state approximation has been used in several studies of N core-level shifts for FeNC [96,97], Casanovas and co-workers have reported that N 1s core-level binding shifts for CNx relevant models mainly arise from initial state effects [98]. We have performed tests using the initial state approximation for N 1s core-level binding shifts for several CNx models and found better agreement with experimental values for quaternary, pyridinic, and pyridinic oxide [46]. Therefore, the Br 3d core B.E. calculations were evaluated under the initial state approximation. The core binding energy was determined as. E core DFT X = E vacuum - E B r 3 d DFT where E B r 3 d DFT is the DFT calculated eigenvalue for Br 3d orbital and E vacuum is the corresponding vacuum level energy. To directly compare with experiments, NaBr was used as a reference and the reported values are corrected using the equation. E core Corrected ( X ) = E core DFT ( X ) + ( E core Experiment N a B r - E core DFT N a B r ) where E core Experiment N a B r is 68.8 eV [99]. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Electrochemical testing: BER performance of CNx Fig. 2 shows the linear sweep voltammograms collected in the range of 0 to 1.6 V for CNx catalyst in the presence of varying amounts of bromide ions in 0.1 M HClO4 electrolyte. While the lower bromide concentration conditions are applicable to water treatment applications, the higher bromide concentration conditions would be more relevant for direct electrocatalytic conversion of bromide ions to bromine gas. The current density associated with BER increases with increasing bromide ion concentration in the electrolyte. When no BER is present in the electrolyte, the LSV represents the OER reaction. With increasing bromide ion concentration, the currents associated with BER become progressively much higher as compared to the OER current on CNx catalyst. The current density at an electrode potential of 1.2 V can be used as a measure of the BER activity of the catalyst (Fig. 2 (inset)). At 1.2 V, the OER current of CNx is negligible as it is the thermodynamic equilibrium potential of OER. It is worthwhile to note from Fig. 2 that the electrochemical oxidation of bromide ions using CNx catalyst begins at Br- concentration as low as 5 mM, as opposed to the minimum bromide ion concentration of ∼ 30 mM required in the traditional non-electrochemical bromine production process using chlorine gas [6]. Table 1 shows the BER selectivity values calculated using RRDE experiments for different bromide ion concentrations at potentials ranging between 1.2 and 1.6 V. The table shows that the BER selectivities at the different low and high bromide ion concentrations are approximately 100 % which implies complete selectivity towards bromine evolution over the competing oxygen evolution reaction. CNx is, therefore, not only active but also highly selective towards BER in an acidic electrolyte. Tafel analysis was performed on CNx catalyst under BER conditions to gain insights into the BER mechanism. At 25 mM Br- concentration in the electrolyte, the Tafel slope was calculated to be ∼ 120 mV/dec indicating that the rate-determining step for BER on CNx is a first electron transfer step (Fig. 3 (a)). However, this electron transfer step is the first step in all three mechanisms – Volmer-Tafel, Volmer-Heyrovsky and Br*-mediated Volmer-Heyrovsky. Therefore, DFT calculations have been performed to further explore the BER mechanism and active sites on CNx. The stability of CNx under BER conditions was determined using accelerated durability testing. The BER LSVs obtained after the catalyst has gone through 300, 500, 700 and 1000 cycles are shown in Fig. 3(b) for a bromide ion concentration of 25 mM. The current densities obtained at 1.2 and 1.3 V are shown in the inset of Fig. 3(b). The results of these accelerated BER durability tests demonstrate that the CNx catalyst is very stable after cycling under highly oxidizing potentials (between 1.1 and 1.4 V) even up to 1000 cycles. Similar results were observed when the potential range during accelerated durability testing was expanded to 1.1 V − 1.5 V, resulting in no drop in the current density up to 500 cycles in the bromide containing electrolyte. These stability results on CNx are also consistent with previously reported tests performed under both ORR and OER conditions [35,52,53]. In the next section, we have focused on comparison of BER activity of the three model catalysts – CNx, 10 % Pt/C (commercial) and Vulcan Carbon (VC, commercial) under the lower bromide concentration conditions and lower overpotentials where OER is insignificant. Fig. 4 compares the electrochemical activity of BER in terms of current density on these three model catalysts. The bromide ion concentration in the electrolyte was varied from 10 to 50 mM and potential hold experiments were performed at 1.2 and 1.3 V. At 10 mM Br- concentration, the BER activity of CNx is slightly lower compared to Pt/C catalyst at both 1.2 V and 1.3 V vs RHE. However, at both 25 mM and 50 mM bromide ion concentrations, the BER activity of CNx is shown to be significantly better than commercial 10 % Pt/C catalyst as evident from BER current densities in Table 2 . As shown in the RRDE experiments and in Fig. 2, there is no measurable OER current density over CNx until after the voltage is increased above 1.3 V; hence there is no contribution from the OER to the current density measured over CNx in this experiment. These results are especially significant considering the much higher cost of Pt-based catalysts as compared to the inexpensive heteroatom-doped carbon-based materials. At all bromide ion concentrations, the BER activity of Vulcan Carbon, a form of commercially available un-doped graphitic carbon, was found to be much less than both Pt/C and CNx catalysts. The next section explores possible active sites on CNx catalyst based on DFT calculations. The possibility of adsorption of intermediates from the competing oxygen evolution reaction is also examined in detail. 4.2 Possible active sites and mechanisms for BER on CNx We performed DFT calculations to evaluate the overpotential for each CNx site model type following each of the three types of BER mechanisms discussed in Section 3.2. These results are presented in a volcano plot shown in Fig. 5 , where the X-axis is the ΔG for either the first Br* adsorption (simple V-H) or the second Br* adsorption (V-T, Br*-mediated V-H mechanisms). For the V-H mechanism the left side of the volcano plot indicates the strong adsorption side, where ΔG(Br*) is negative and the initial Br* adsorption is favorable below the thermodynamic BER potential of 1.07 V-RHE. Therefore, for sites on the left side of the volcano plot the potential determining step is desorption of Br* and the applied potential must be increased until ΔG for removal of Br* becomes zero (the second step in V-H mechanism). On the other hand, the right side of the volcano plot indicates the weak adsorption side where the potential determining step is the adsorption of the Br* species. Therefore, when on the right side of the volcano plot, the adsorption of an adjacent Br* species (required for V-T and Br*-mediated V-H mechanisms) is not relevant since the first Br* species adsorption is potential determining and the only relevant mechanism for such sites will be the V-H mechanism. Focusing on the simple Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism (represented by solid orange circles in Fig. 5) shows that the zigzag oxide and pyrrolic oxide sites are the most active sites with overpotentials of 0.12 and 0.15 V-RHE, respectively. For the zigzag oxide the potential determining step is desorption of Br* because it is on the left side of the volcano, whereas for the pyrolic oxide, the potential determining step is adsorption of the Br* because it is on the right side. In addition, several sites (zigzag oxide, zigzag pyridinic, pyrrolic, zigzag quaternary, basal quaternary, and armchair quaternary) fall on the strong binding (left) side of the volcano plot. All these sites are candidates to proceed via the V-T or Br*-mediated V-H mechanism. The armchair oxide, armchair pyridinic, and full graphene sites are on the weak binding (right) side of the volcano plot and have large overpotentials – we can consider these sites to be inactive for BER. It is worth noting that full graphene sites have extremely weak binding of Br*, therefore we can view the CNx catalysts active sites to solely come from local N-doped structures. However, clearly only some of these local N-doped structures are active for BER. We examined the adsorption of an adjacent Br* for the strong binding CNx sites of zigzag oxide, zigzag pyridinic, pyrrolic, zigzag quaternary, basal quaternary, and armchair quaternary. For sites where the adsorption of a second Br* is favorable over the V-H mechanism on the initial Br*, we examined the free energy of reaction of the third step of the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism and the V-T mechanism. The results for these calculations are summarized in Table 3 at an applied potential of 1.07 V-RHE. We find that the adsorption of the second Br* has a positive ΔG for all the six sites, and as shown in the volcano plot (Fig. 5, blue symbols), this results in a universal shift of these sites to the weak binding side of the volcano plot. The weak binding of the second Br* can be attributed to the ion-ion repulsion effects taking place on the CNx surface as multiple bromide ions are adsorbed. This repulsion can be observed in Fig. 6 , which illustrates the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism on zigzag quaternary site, where the two Br* species orient away from each other to minimize the repulsive interactions. Comparing ΔG2 (second Br* adsorption) versus ΔG1 (initial Br* adsorption) in Table 3 indicates that for zigzag oxide, zigzag pyridinic, and pyrrolic sites, considering the V-H mechanism to take place with this second, more weakly adsorbed bromide ion would be less favored than the initial V-H mechanism as the overpotential is increased. However, for the armchair quaternary, zigzag quaternary, and basal quaternary sites, the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism would be more favored due to a decrease in overpotential. As shown in Fig. 6, for the zigzag quaternary site the overpotential goes from 0.37 V-RHE via the V-H mechanism to 0.03 V-RHE via the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism. This is reflected in the volcano plot of Fig. 5, where the zigzag quaternary site shifts to the right for the second Br* adsorption but this shift leads to the top of the volcano and the smallest overpotential. Therefore, by considering the possibility of V-H mechanism taking place adjacent to a strongly bound Br*, we find that the zigzag quaternary site is even more active for BER than the zigzag oxide and pyrrolic oxide sites, but all three proceed via a V-H mechanism. The V-T mechanism includes a non-electrochemical reaction step for the third step and thus this step cannot be affected by applied potential. Table 3 shows that for the zigzag quaternary and basal quaternary sites, ΔG3 (V-T) is positive in free energy and, thus, we conclude that BER would not proceed through the V-T mechanism on these sites. This is a first order approximation and barriers would need to be evaluated to fully determine if these steps could proceed at room temperature at appreciable rates. Alternatively, if ΔG3 (V-T) is negative in free energy, as in the case of the zigzag oxide, zigzag pyridinic, and pyrrolic sites, then BER could occur at an overpotential like that of the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism due to the potential determining step for both mechanisms being the second step of adsorbing the adjacent Br*. This overlap between V-T and Br*-mediated V-H mechanisms are reflected in Fig. 5 where both mechanisms are at the same overpotential. Considering all three types of mechanisms, the most active sites from this analysis are zigzag quaternary (Br*-mediated V-H), zigzag oxide (V-H), and pyrrolic oxide (V-H) with overpotentials of 0.03, 0.12, and 0.15 V-RHE, respectively. However, this analysis only considers the BER mechanisms on the CNx sites. In the next section we examine the role of OER intermediates to see if they can modify the DFT predictions of the active site for BER. 4.3 Role of competing surface intermediates from OER on BER active sites Since the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) has a thermodynamic potential (1.23 V) that is close to the operating potentials for BER (1.07 V), intermediates from OER can potentially outcompete Br* formation. Such OER intermediates would modify the CNx active sites under reaction conditions even below the thermodynamic potentials for either reaction. These modifications could lead to site blocking (poisoning BER) or BER activity adjacent to OER intermediates (enhancing BER). We have examined the OER mechanism on each of the CNx active sites. Details of the OER mechanism and the results of the DFT calculations can be found in the SI. Here our interest is in identifying the OER intermediates that are stable on the CNx site at potentials below 1.07 V-RHE that could potentially impact BER activity. Fig. 7 plots the potential for the first stable species of OER along with the potential for the first Br* adsorption on all the CNx site models. Fig. 7 reveals that OH* forms on the surface before Br* for the pyrrolic, pyrrolic oxide, zigzag oxide, and zigzag pyridinic CNx sites at potentials well below the thermodynamic potentials of BER or OER. The quaternary-type sites show an exception to this trend, exhibiting different behaviors ranging from significant competition on the zigzag quaternary site between Br* and the OER intermediate to binding Br* more strongly than OH* on the armchair quaternary and basal quaternary sites. On zigzag quaternary, both OH* and O* show large negative ΔG values (see Table S2) and so we would expect that O* would be the stable OER intermediate and form even at potentials as low as 0.67 V-RHE as indicated in Fig. 7. To understand how the formation of stable OER intermediates can affect the BER mechanism, we consider a variation of the Br*-mediated V-H BER mechanism discussed in Section 4.2. Here the reaction steps proceed when an OH* intermediate from the competing OER reaction forms initially on the CNx site before subsequent Br* adsorption and turnover via V-H mechanism. We refer to this mechanism as the OH*-mediated V-H mechanism. As in the Br*-mediated V-H BER mechanism, the first step in the below scheme is an initiation step and steps 2 and 3 are repeated via a V-H mechanism to produce bromine gas. H 2 O ( a q ) + ∗ A → OH A ∗ + H + + e - OH A ∗ + Br - a q + ∗ B → OH A ∗ + Br B ∗ + e - OH A ∗ + Br B ∗ + Br - a q → Br 2 g + OH A ∗ + ∗ B + e - Table 4 shows ΔG at 1.07 V-RHE for the initial competition between Br* and OH* formation and then for sites where OH* can outcompete Br* it presents the ΔG for possible second steps. These second steps can include Br* or OH* formation on adjacent sites or the formation of O* (the next step in OER). The CNx sites that show weak binding for initial Br* formation (armchair oxide, armchair pyridinic, and full graphene) are not shown in Table 4 since for all three sites OH* formation is also not favored until higher applied potentials (see Fig. 7). Therefore, we can conclude that OER intermediates are not going to convert these sites from inactive to active structures. We interpret the data in Table 4 for the catalyst system with the potential sweeping from 0 to 1.6 V-RHE as in the experiment. For armchair quaternary and basal quaternary sites, Br* formation shows a larger negative ΔG than OH* formation and therefore Br* will form at more negative potentials (as also observed in Fig. 7). Because these sites were not the most active sites for BER (see volcano plot of Fig. 5) we do not explore if the second Br* can outcompete OH* formation. This leaves 5 sites that have OH* forming before Br* as the initial step as shown in Table 4. For four of these sites the next step in OER (conversion to O*) is not favored and the relevant question is the competition between OH* and Br* formation on the adjacent site. Zigzag quaternary is a more complex situation since as soon as OH* forms the next step to form O* is also favored due to a negative ΔG (see Table 4). We will return to this site further below. The pyrrolic site prefers the formation of a second OH* intermediate (-0.15 eV) over Br* formation (+0.66 eV) and the OH-OH* structure would form at an applied potential of 0.92 V-RHE. Therefore, we conclude that the pyrrolic site is not an active site for BER, however, it may serve to catalyze OER as it favors formation of multiple OH* intermediates. The OER mechanism on CNx catalysts will be the focus of future studies. The zigzag oxide, zigzag pyridinic, and pyrrolic oxide sites all have Br* forming preferentially adjacent to the first OH* intermediate. For these sites, the BER can proceed through the OH*-mediated V-H mechanism as shown in Fig. 8 . The overpotential for zigzag pyridinic is 0.07 V-RHE through the OH*-mediated V-H mechanism. Without the consideration of OER intermediates, the zigzag pyridinic had an overpotential of 0.35 V-RHE. This large difference illustrates the importance of incorporating the competing OER intermediates into the DFT evaluation of BER activity. Interestingly, the pyrrolic oxide has the same predicted overpotential (0.15 V-RHE) but now proceeds through the OH*-mediated V-H mechanism. Finally, the zigzag oxide site which in the absence of OER intermediates proceeded via a V-H mechanism with a overpotential of 0.12 V-RHE will now be affected by the formation of OH* and the overpotential is predicted to be 0.23 V-RHE. Therefore, in this case the presence of OER intermediates (which cannot be avoided) would make this site less active than initially predicted. We note that for the pyrrolic oxide site, the formation of Br*–OH* (0.15 eV) is only slightly favored over OH*–OH* (0.24 eV). This suggests that this site may only be active for a narrow potential range before OH*–OH* forms and effectively blocks this site for BER activity. In contrast, for the zigzag oxide and zigzag pyridinic sites the formation of OH*–OH* requires high potentials and would not compete with BER in any relevant applied potentials. For all three sites, the BER proceeds with the first electron transfer step to form Br* as the potential-determining step, which is in good agreement with the experimental Tafel slope measurements. We conclude the discussion of active sites by examining the zigzag quaternary site, which in the initial analysis of the BER mechanism was predicted to be the most active site with a overpotential of 0.03 V-RHE. There are multiple scenarios that are possible on zigzag quaternary since the formation of OH* (-0.40 eV) is similar to Br* (-0.37 eV). We have examined scenarios where the first site is occupied by Br* and alternatively when OH* formation occurs first. One may initally expect that if Br* forms first, that potentially BER could proceed via the Br*-mediated V-H mechanism as presented in Section 4.2. However, we find that even if Br* forms first that the next step will be the formation of an adjacent OH* (ΔG of −1.08 eV) rather than the formation of Br2 which has a ΔG value of + 0.03 eV. Furthermore, this Br*–OH* complex cannot form Br2 via V-H step or convert to Br*-O* (next step of OER) until applied potentials of greater than 1.65 V-RHE. If on the other hand, OH* forms initially, we find that the formation of either adjacent Br* (-1.05 eV) or adjacent OH* (-0.93 eV) is favored. In addition, the OH* can also convert to O* (-0.96 eV) favorably once the initial OH* forms. All these scenarios are equally likely since they would all be downhill after the initial OH* formation (that would occur at 0.67 V-RHE). However, all these various configurations (OH-Br*, OH*–OH*, or O*) do not undergo the next step until much more positive potentials. Therefore, despite the rather complex set of possible scenarios on zigzag quaternary site all of them lead to strongly bound Br* species or OER intermediates that are a dead-end for BER. We conclude that with the incorporation of OER intermediates, the zigzag quaternary site is one of the poorest sites for BER. Again this shows the importance of the OER intermediates since the zigzag quaternary site would have been considered the most active site if the possibility of OER intermediate formation was not examined. In conclusion, incorporating the OER intermediates we find the most active sites for BER at potentials near 1.2 V-RHE are zigzag pyridinic, zigzag oxide, and pyrrolic oxide and that these sites turn over the BER through a V-H mechanism that occurs with an OH* intermediate adsorbed on an adjacent site. 4.4 Post-reaction X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 9 shows the Br-3d XPS spectra collected on the catalyst coated CNx electrode after being exposed to an applied potential of 1.2 V, both in the absence of Br- anions in the electrolyte as well as in the presence of 50 mM Br- anions in the electrolyte. As expected, no bromine is observed on the electrode to which potential was applied in the Br- - free electrolyte. However, the electrode tip exposed to Br- anions under an applied potential of 1.2 V shows three clear regions in its Br-3d XPS spectrum. The Br-3d XPS spectrum is fitted using three different species, each with its respective Br-3d3/2 and Br-3d5/2 spin orbit components separated by a binding energy of 1.05 eV. The distribution of these different species is reported in Table 5 . Based on DFT calculations of XPS binding energies reported in Table 5, the 3d5/2 XPS peak observed at 69.8 eV corresponds to the presence of several C-Br species on different CNx sites including Br-OH* on zigzag oxide, Br-OH* on zigzag pyridinic, Br2* on basal quaternary, Br* on zigzag quaternary and Br-Br* on zigzag quaternary. This observation is consistent with C-Br binding energies reported in the literature [100]. The second XPS component at Br-3d5/2 binding energy of 68.1 eV corresponds to Br-OH* on pyrrolic oxide. This component also indicates the presence of unreacted Br- anions adsorbed on the surface of the CNx electrode [101]. Lastly, the XPS peak at 3d5/2 binding energy of 66.9 eV can be attributed to the presence of Br* on basal quaternary sites, which are also the most abundant type of nitrogen sites in the CNx catalyst, as reported in our previous works [35,36,46]. This observation is also consistent with DFT findings that the basal quaternary site favors strong Br* adsorption instead of OH* or Br-OH* formation. However, it should be noted that basal quaternary is not a favored site for BER since it binds Br* too strongly. Overall, the specific types of BER intermediates (including the presence of Br-OH* structures) that were calculated to thermodynamically form on the candidate CNx active sites using DFT also appear in the XPS spectra. This suggests that the mechanisms considered for BER are indeed viable and serves as an added screening process when assessing the changes that may take place on or to the catalyst surfaces during operating conditions. 5 Conclusion This work demonstrates the potential of using CNx catalyst for bromine evolution reaction in a variety of applications. The electrochemical BER activity of CNx is shown to be significantly higher than traditional graphite-based or precious-metal based electrodes. Moreover, the high BER activity of CNx is accompanied by high BER selectivity (low OER selectivity). The CNx catalyst is also found to be stable despite the strongly oxidizing potentials required for BER. These experimental results are complimented with DFT calculations aimed at identifying the potential BER active sites and mechanism in CNx. DFT calculations initially examining just the BER mechanisms on the CNx sites conclude that BER can occur through both a simple Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism and a Br*-mediated Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism where the BER proceeds through a second adjacent Br*. However, when the possibility of OER intermediates is incorporated DFT predicts the majority of the sites show initial OH* formation and subsequent BER occurs through a OH*-mediated Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism where the Br* forms adjacent to the OH* species. More broadly the DFT study shows the importance of OER intermediates to change the activity of CNx sites and that the actual CNx surface under reaction conditions will have OH* species present. Computational XPS was able to confirm the presence of DFT-determined BER intermediates on CNx sites by fitting calculated binding energy values to experimental Br-3d XPS spectra with good agreement. This study is an important first step in the design of electrocatalyst materials and the exploration of active sites on CNx for electrochemical bromine evolution reaction. coredata.dc:description: Electrocatalytic bromine evolution reaction (BER) is significant for bromine production, energy storage, and wastewater treatment applications. Previously reported electrocatalysts for BER either include unstable graphite anodes or precious metal-containing materials. To overcome their disadvantages, this work has proposed, for the first time, the use of nitrogen-doped carbon nanostructures (CNx) as anode catalysts for BER in acidic medium. In terms of BER activity, CNx outperforms both Vulcan Carbon and commercial 10 % Pt/C at bromide concentration as low as 0.025 M. CNx also exhibits high BER selectivity and remarkable stability at highly oxidizing potentials. Tafel slope was measured to be ∼ 120 mV/dec supporting a first electron transfer limiting step for BER on CNx. The high activity and stability of CNx is attributed to several nitrogen-doped carbon sites in its graphitic matrix, which have been examined using DFT. The inclusion of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) intermediates is critical to identify BER active sites accurately, as the most active sites (zigzag pyridinic, zigzag oxide, and pyrrolic oxide) proceed via a OH*-mediated Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. For these sites, DFT predicts that the potential determining step is the first electron transfer to form Br* in agreement with the experimental Tafel slope. Comparison to post-reaction XPS shows good agreement between DFT predicted Br* structures. This work thus provides a direction for the rational design of CNx electrocatalysts for BER.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active nitrogen – doped carbon nanostructures as electrocatalysts for bromine evolution reaction: A combined experimental and DFT study
